concat.scalar: Resellers and distributors are both types of business partners in the IBM Partner Ecosystem. However, there are some key differences between them.

Resellers are independent entities that have the authority to sell IBM software, hardware products, cloud services, and professional services directly to end-user customers. They own the relationship with their customers, set their own pricing and terms, and may even compete with IBM for business.

On the other hand, distributors are a type of reseller that only sells to other IBM resellers. They provide support and other benefits to resellers, which helps IBM avoid the need to provide those services directly.
In summary, resellers have the freedom to sell IBM products and services directly to end-users, while distributors focus on selling to other resellers and providing support to them.

The key requirement in an Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA) is the partner solution use case. An ESA allows partners to obtain rights to embed IBM's software or hardware technology into a product, solution, or service to sell to clients. The ESA offers partners a flexible commercial model that enabl

es them to create and offer solutions that industries require, consumed the way they want it, priced the way they need it to be. Partners can leverage IBM's innovative and market-tested technologies like AI, advanced analytics, and security to enhance their solution in a build versus bimodal that al

lows them to accelerate their go-to-market readiness with flexible pricing and costs aligned to industry standards that are integrated into their pricing in metrics that they use for their solution to their end customers.

The ESA program is the primary contract supporting the 'Build with IBM' program. It is designed to help partners accelerate their go-to-market readiness with flexible pricing and costs aligned to industry standards. The ESA allows partners to leverage IBM's innovative and market-tested technologies

like AI, advanced analytics, and security to enhance their solution. The key requirement in an ESA is the partner solution use case. Partners must have a clear understanding of their solution's use case and how it will benefit their clients. They must also have the technical expertise to integrate I
BM's technology into their solution.

For more information on the Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA), partners can refer to the IBM documentation provided. The documentation provides a comprehensive overview of the ESA program, its benefits, and requirements. Additionally, partners can reach out to their IBM sales representative for more
information on the ESA program and how to get started.

Communication plays a crucial role in setting joint expectations and building successful business partnerships. By effectively communicating with your partner, you can establish a clear understanding of each other's strengths, capabilities, and goals. This knowledge allows you to align your strategi
es and work together towards a common objective.

When setting joint expectations, open and transparent communication is essential. Clearly communicate your expectations and requirements to your partner, and encourage them to do the same. This ensures that both parties are on the same page and have a shared understanding of what needs to be achieve
d. It also helps in avoiding misunderstandings and conflicts down the line.

In front of a client, it is important to communicate how you and your partner work together. This demonstrates a unified front and builds trust with the client. By showcasing a seamless collaboration, you can instill confidence in the client that they are receiving a comprehensive solution from both
you and your partner.

Furthermore, communication plays a vital role in sharing opportunities. By openly discussing potential business opportunities, you can identify areas where your partner's strengths can be leveraged, and vice versa. This not only helps in expanding the scope of your partnership but also strengthens t
he trust and mutual respect between both parties.

However, it is crucial to respect boundaries and not share confidential information. While open communication is encouraged, it is important to maintain the confidentiality of sensitive information. This ensures that both you and your partner can trust each other with valuable data and maintain the
integrity of the partnership.

To ensure that businesses and their partners are working towards a common goal, it is important to establish joint expectations and be clear in front of clients about how the partnership works. Sharing opportunities is also essential to build and extend trust in the partnership, while respecting bou

ndaries and not sharing confidential information. Recognizing working deals, determining routes to market, and avoiding engagement where IBM or another partner already has the lead can also help align goals.

Additionally, IBM offers business partner summits and other integrity sessions for both IBM business partners and sellers to encourage collaboration and ensure equitable treatment of all partners. It is also important to have a single-source IT financing option that can combine leases and payment pl
ans for consolidated billing to simplify the process and add speed and efficiency to the sales cycle.

Joining IBM Partner Plus and unlocking benefits aligned to the business journey, building with IBM to bring ideas to market quickly, enhancing solutions by embedding IBMâ€™s innovative and market-leading technology, and making use of IBM resources to empower the growth of the business can also help ac
hieve alignment and common goals.

Overall, clear communication, joint expectations, sharing opportunities, recognizing working deals, and utilizing available resources can help businesses and their partners work towards a common goal and achieve alignment.
When working with business partners, there are several best practices that can help build trust and respect between parties.

Firstly, it is important to understand and leverage the strengths and capabilities of your business partner. This means taking the time to get to know their expertise and how it aligns with your own. By recognizing and utilizing each other's strengths, you can create a more collaborative and effecti
ve partnership.

Secondly, clear communication and setting joint expectations are crucial. It is important to have open and transparent communication with your business partner, especially when interacting with clients. Clearly communicate your joint strategy and work together to ensure that both parties are on the
same page.

Sharing opportunities is another key practice. By sharing opportunities with your business partner, you can build trust and demonstrate that you value their contribution. This can lead to a more mutually beneficial partnership and strengthen the overall relationship.

Respecting boundaries is also essential. It is important to not share any confidential information with other business partners or clients without proper authorization. Respecting boundaries helps maintain trust and confidentiality within the partnership.

Lastly, recognizing working deals and determining routes to market is important. If IBM or another business partner already has the lead on a particular opportunity, it is best to avoid engagement and instead focus on other potential opportunities. This shows respect for the efforts and investments
made by other parties and helps maintain a positive and collaborative environment.
By following these best practices, business partners can build trust and respect between parties, leading to a stronger and more successful partnership.

IBM business partners and sellers work together in a collaborative manner to provide clients with the best technology solutions available. By leveraging their established, trusted relationships with clients, IBM business partners greatly influence technology decisions. They offer comprehensive solut
ions embedded with IBM technology, utilizing their deep technical and sales skills.

One of the key advantages of working with IBM business partners is their ability to exponentially expand territory reach. With a larger number of business partner sellers compared to IBMers, they can effectively cover a wider client base and tap into niche market segments. This increased reach and l
ocal presence allow them to serve as trusted advisors to clients, driving IBM offerings and solutions.

The collaboration between IBM business partners and sellers is mutually beneficial. By encouraging collaboration, the program helps business partners capitalize on IBM's relationship with the client and tap into IBM's industry and technology expertise. This creates more opportunities for both partie
s and leads to enhanced and expanding engagements.

In this partner ecosystem, business partner sellers have the opportunity to earn and win business at IBM covered accounts in collaboration with IBM sellers. By working together as a sales team to support the deal, both IBM sellers and business partner sellers can achieve success. Ultimately, the cli
ents are the ones who benefit the most from this collaboration, as they receive the best technology solution available.
Overall, the partnership between IBM business partners and sellers is built on trust, expertise, and a shared goal of providing clients with the most effective technology solutions.
IBM business partners gain several benefits from collaborating with IBM sellers and leveraging IBM's industry and technology expertise.

Firstly, collaborating with IBM sellers allows business partners to increase their reach and local presence. By working together, they can tap into IBM's extensive network and customer base, which opens up new business opportunities and expands their market reach.

Secondly, IBM's industry and technology expertise provide valuable insights and resources for business partners. IBM has a long history of innovation and a deep understanding of various industries. By leveraging IBM's expertise, business partners can enhance their offerings and provide greater value
to their clients. This expertise can also help business partners stay ahead of industry trends and developments, enabling them to offer cutting-edge solutions to their clients.

Additionally, collaborating with IBM sellers gives business partners access to a strong marketing and communications engine. This helps in prospecting new business faster and increasing brand visibility. IBM's streamlined go-to-market model also provides increased brand and technical sales coverage,
which can unlock new business opportunities for business partners.

Furthermore, by working together as a single team, business partners and IBM can deliver consistent client experiences. This client-centric approach ensures that engagements are tailored to meet the specific needs and preferences of clients and partners. The IBM ecosystem strategy positions the clie
nt at the center, emphasizing the importance of collaboration and joint success.

Overall, collaborating with IBM sellers and leveraging IBM's industry and technology expertise allows business partners to expand their market reach, enhance their offerings, access a strong marketing engine, and deliver consistent client experiences.

IBM business partners can work with IBM sellers to increase business and revenue opportunities by collaborating and co-selling across all territories. Business partners can tap into IBM's industry and technology expertise to create more opportunities and expand their engagement with clients. IBM sel

lers can help business partners capitalize on IBM's relationship with clients and provide enablement at the point of opportunity. By encouraging collaboration, the program can help IBM business partners grow their capabilities through partner technical activation plans and partner account plans. Add

itionally, IBM offers resources and personalized support to help business partners market and globally promote their solutions, reach new clients, and maximize their market opportunity. By working together, IBM business partners and sellers can create innovative solutions with embedded IBM technolog
y, accelerate co-creation, and drive revenue growth for both parties.

IBM Financing offers customized payment options for bundled solutions to meet the specific financial goals and requirements of clients. These options include custom payment plans, fair market value and full payout leases, loans, and standard payment plans for software. These payment structures can b
e tailored to match the client's budget and budget cycle, providing convenience and flexibility.

In addition to the core offerings, IBM Financing also provides non-standard payment terms for clients who have unique financial needs. These non-standard payment terms are designed to accommodate specific financial goals or requirements of the clients. By offering flexible payment structures, IBM Fi
nancing aims to ensure that clients can access the technology solutions they need while managing their finances effectively.

It is important to note that the specific examples of customized payment options may vary depending on the client's requirements and the bundled solutions being financed. IBM Financing works closely with clients to understand their needs and develop tailored payment structures that align with their
financial objectives.

Overall, IBM Financing's goal is to enhance cash flow, optimize budget, and lower the total cost of ownership for clients by providing a range of flexible and customized payment options for bundled solutions across the IBM technology portfolio.

Offering flexible financing options for clients can provide several benefits and have a significant impact on the total cost of ownership. Firstly, flexible financing allows clients to start projects quickly by providing them with the necessary funds upfront. This eliminates the need for clients to
allocate a large sum of money from their budget immediately, which can be especially beneficial for businesses with limited cash flow.

Moreover, flexible financing options can enhance a client's cash flow by spreading out the payments over a period of time. This means that clients can manage their expenses more effectively and allocate their resources to other critical areas of their business. By aligning payments with the client's
budget cycle, financing solutions ensure that the financial burden is minimized and the client can maintain a healthy cash flow.

In terms of total cost of ownership (TCO), flexible financing can help lower it. By matching payments to the client's budget, financing solutions enable clients to avoid large upfront costs and instead make affordable payments over time. This can result in a lower TCO as clients can spread out the e
xpenses associated with acquiring and maintaining technology solutions.

Additionally, customized payment options for bundled solutions further contribute to reducing the TCO. By offering financing for the entire solution, clients can benefit from a single point of contact, streamlined support, and simplified management. This not only reduces the administrative burden bu
t also ensures a high-performance and reliable solution for the client.
Furthermore, financing solutions, such as residual value leasing, allow clients to achieve lower payments and lower TCO.

IBM Financing helps clients accelerate opportunities and optimize their budgets by providing flexible payment plans and leasing solutions. With IBM Financing, clients can enhance their cash flow and return on investment (ROI) by spreading out the cost of their technology investments over time. This
allows clients to allocate their budget more efficiently and effectively.

By offering customized financing options, IBM Financing can match payments to the client's budget and financial goals. This helps clients avoid large upfront costs and enables them to invest in the latest technology solutions without straining their financial resources. Additionally, IBM Financing h
elps lower the total cost of ownership (TCO) by providing competitive interest rates and favorable terms.

Furthermore, IBM Financing enables clients to take advantage of the latest technology innovations and solutions without delay. By providing access to flexible financing options, clients can quickly implement new technologies and stay ahead of their competition. This helps accelerate opportunities fo
r growth and innovation.

In addition to financing solutions, IBM Financing also offers the IBM Financing Hub, an integrated platform that provides self-serve capabilities for quoting, credit, and contracting. This streamlined process allows clients to easily access and manage their financing agreements, saving time and effo
rt.

Overall, IBM Financing is a trusted partner with over 40 years of experience in delivering client value. By optimizing budgets and providing flexible financing options, IBM Financing helps clients accelerate opportunities, enhance cash flow, and achieve their business objectives.

IBM provides several resources to help business partners understand and navigate the legal and ethical considerations of working with IBM. These resources include the IBM Business Partner Code of Conduct, which defines minimum business conduct and practice standards that BPs are to comply with in th

eir relationship with IBM. Additionally, the Guidelines for Working With IBM Business Partners provide internal documentation that defines IBM policies and practices on numerous topics when supporting Business Partners.

IBM also offers contract templates for Business Partner contracts, including BPAs, ESAs, Cloud Marketplace, and more. These templates can be found on the IBM Partner Ecosystem Contract Documents page.

The Partner Ecosystem Legal Page contains details about the Partner Ecosystem Legal Team, including information on reporting to IBM if you encounter an unlawful or unethical situation. IBM also has a Business Partner Compliance Program that outlines the elements of an effective compliance program.

Furthermore, IBM expects the highest ethical and integrity standards from IBM sellers and asks the same from its partners. Having a business environment where trustworthy actions set the foundation for any business relationship is pivotal for our joint success. IBM encourages business partners to co
nsult with IBM Management, Legal, Trust & Compliance, and/or any Communication Channel if they have any questions or are aware of or suspect any improper conduct in this space.

In summary, IBM provides a variety of resources to help business partners understand and navigate the legal and ethical considerations of working with IBM, including codes of conduct, guidelines, contract templates, compliance programs, and access to legal and compliance teams.
Business partners, including resellers and distributors, differ from IBM direct sales in several ways, and these differences have implications for legal risks.

Firstly, business partners are independent entities from IBM. They have their own marketing strategies, set their own pricing and terms, and may even compete with each other. This independence means that IBM has limited control over the actions and decisions of its business partners, which can incre
ase legal risks.

Secondly, business partners have the ability to sell for IBM competitors. Unlike IBM direct sales, business partners are not exclusive to IBM and can offer products or services from other companies. This creates a potential conflict of interest and can lead to legal risks, such as breaches of non-co
mpete agreements or intellectual property rights.

Additionally, business partners can compete directly with IBM and other IBM business partners. This competitive environment can result in legal risks related to unfair competition, such as false advertising or misrepresentation of products or services.

When working with business partners, IBM pays special attention to the discounts provided to them. Excessive discounts can raise concerns about bribery or the creation of slush funds. IBM closely scrutinizes the justifications for providing discounts and their amounts to mitigate these risks.

Furthermore, IBM takes measures to ensure that the end user prices quoted by third parties are the actual prices paid by the end users. This is done through methods such as setting limits on the maximum end user price, post-ship verification, and transparency letters. These measures help prevent pri
ce manipulation and maintain transparency in business partner transactions.

In the IBM Partner Ecosystem, there are key differences between resellers and distributors, as well as compared to direct sales. Resellers and distributors are both types of business partners, but they have distinct characteristics and roles within the ecosystem.

Resellers are independent entities from IBM that sell IBM products and services to end users. They set their own pricing and terms, and they may also compete with each other. Resellers are responsible for marketing and selling IBM products to customers, and they play a crucial role in reaching a wid
er customer base.

On the other hand, distributors are also independent entities from IBM, but their primary role is to distribute IBM products to resellers. They act as intermediaries between IBM and resellers, handling logistics, inventory management, and order fulfillment. Distributors help streamline the supply ch
ain and ensure that resellers have access to a wide range of IBM products.

Compared to direct sales, working with resellers and distributors introduces additional legal risks for IBM. This is because resellers and distributors are independent entities that have their own business strategies and may also sell products from IBM's competitors. They have the freedom to set the
ir own pricing and terms, which can lead to variations in the market and potential conflicts with IBM's pricing policies.
Furthermore, resellers and distributors can compete directly with IBM and other IBM business partners. This competition can create challenges in terms of market share and customer loyalty.

The IBM Build Lab team provides technical resources, experts, and support to help businesses validate their solutions with IBM Cloud for Financial Services. This includes hands-on support for technical architecture validation and assistance in solution migration. The team acts as a guide and collabo

rator, helping businesses to leverage the greatest benefits of IBM technologies such as Red Hat OpenShift, IBM Cloud Pak, IBM Watson, and the IBM Cloud platform in their solutions. Additionally, the Build Lab team helps businesses acquire critical skills needed to expedite development and maximize t

he value of open hybrid cloud and AI built on or with IBM technology. Overall, the IBM Build Lab team is dedicated to helping businesses co-create solutions with embedded IBM technology and providing the necessary support and resources to ensure success.

Businesses can leverage IBM technologies to embed AI into their solutions through the Build Program offered by IBM. This program provides technical resources, experts, and support to accelerate the co-creation of solutions with embedded IBM technology, with a specific focus on AI. By working with IB
M's technology teams, businesses can access experts, training, and education to support product design and validation.

The benefits of embedding AI into solutions with IBM technology are numerous. Firstly, businesses can bring their ideas to market quickly by leveraging IBM's innovative and market-leading technology. This can help them stay ahead of the competition and meet the evolving needs of their customers.

Additionally, businesses can enhance their solutions by embedding IBM's AI technologies, such as the Embeddable AI suite. These enterprise-grade core AI technologies have a flexible form factor and are easy to embed in solutions. By incorporating AI capabilities, businesses can improve the performan
ce, efficiency, and intelligence of their solutions, leading to better outcomes for their customers.

Furthermore, businesses can expect technical expertise and support from IBM throughout the integration phase of embedding IBM technology. This ensures a smooth and successful integration process, reducing time-to-market and minimizing potential issues.

From a commercial perspective, businesses can benefit from flexible terms and pricing through the Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA). This allows them to control and predict their costs, enabling better financial planning. The ESA also supports the creation of the right commercial model construct tha
t aligns with how businesses position and sell their solutions in the market.

The IBM Build Lab team offers a range of technologies to help businesses migrate or modernize their solutions for hybrid cloud. These technologies include Red Hat OpenShift, IBM Cloud Pak, IBM Watson, and the IBM Cloud platform. With Red Hat OpenShift, businesses can build, deploy, and manage applic

ations across hybrid cloud environments. IBM Cloud Pak provides a containerized software solution that helps businesses modernize their applications and infrastructure. IBM Watson offers AI-powered services and tools that businesses can integrate into their solutions to enhance functionality and int

elligence. The IBM Cloud platform provides a robust and scalable infrastructure for businesses to host their applications and data in a hybrid cloud environment. By leveraging these technologies, businesses can expedite development, validate their solutions, and maximize the value of open hybrid clo
ud and AI built on or with IBM technology.

Clients can access financing solutions and manage their accounts through the IBM Financing Hub, an integrated financing platform. The IBM Financing Hub provides self-serve capabilities for quoting, credit, and contracting. This means that clients can easily navigate the platform to explore financing
options, obtain quotes, and manage their accounts.

To access financing solutions through the IBM Financing Hub, clients need to be qualified commercial or government clients. The offerings are provided through IBM subsidiaries and divisions worldwide. In the United States, IBM Financing lease and financing offerings are provided through IBM Credit L
LC.

The availability and rates of financing solutions may vary based on factors such as the client's credit rating, financing terms, offering type, equipment, and product type and options. It is important to note that the offering does not guarantee that credit will be provided.

Through the IBM Financing Hub, clients can also manage their accounts. This includes monitoring their financing agreements, making payments, and accessing account information. The platform provides a convenient and centralized way for clients to stay on top of their financing arrangements.

Overall, the IBM Financing Hub offers clients a streamlined and user-friendly experience for accessing financing solutions and managing their accounts. It is designed to help accelerate opportunities and improve the deal win rate, providing clients with the flexibility and support they need to grow
their businesses.

The financing options available to clients through IBM Global Finance are determined by several factors. These factors include the client's credit rating, financing terms, offering type, equipment, and product type and options. The rates and availability of financing may also vary by country. It is

important to note that this offering does not guarantee that credit will be provided. Additionally, non-IBM content, which is part of an overall IBM end-user client solution, may also be eligible for financing through IBM Financing. Non-hardware items are financed by means of loans. Other restrictio

ns may apply, and rates and offerings are subject to change, extension, or withdrawal without notice and may not be available in all countries. It is also important to note that IBM and IBM Financing do not offer or provide accounting, tax, or legal advice to clients.

IBM Global Finance provides lease and financing offerings to qualified commercial and government clients in the United States. These offerings are provided through IBM Credit LLC. The rates and availability of these offerings are based on various factors such as the client's credit rating, financing

terms, offering type, equipment and product type, and options. It is important to note that this offering does not guarantee that credit will be provided. Additionally, non-IBM content that is part of an overall IBM end user client solution may also be eligible for financing through IBM Global Fina
nce.

Yes, IBM can provide more information on the IBM Integrity and Compliance program and how it helps business partners understand and adhere to legal and ethical requirements. The IBM Integrity and Compliance program is designed to ensure that IBM and its business partners operate with the highest eth

ical standards and comply with all applicable laws and regulations. The program includes the IBM Business Conduct Guidelines, which provide guidance on ethical behavior and compliance with laws and regulations, as well as the IBM Relationship Revalidation program, which engages business partners to
provide updated information on their companies, acknowledge the IBM Code of Conduct, and take a short Integrity Course.

The IBM Business Partner Compliance Program is another important component of the Integrity and Compliance program. This program outlines the elements of an effective compliance program and provides guidance on how business partners can develop and implement their own compliance programs. The progra
m also includes training and resources to help business partners understand and comply with legal and ethical requirements.

In addition, IBM has a reporting mechanism in place for anyone who encounters an unlawful or unethical situation. Employees, business partners, and other stakeholders can report any concerns or allegations through IBM's Concerns & Appeals program. IBM also encourages individuals to consult with IBM
Management, Legal, Trust & Compliance, and/or any Communication Channel if they have any questions or are aware of or suspect any improper conduct.

Overall, the IBM Integrity and Compliance program is a comprehensive approach to ensuring that IBM and its business partners operate with the highest ethical standards and comply with all applicable laws and regulations.
Businesses can ensure compliance with anti-corruption laws, such as the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), when working with international partners by implementing several key measures.

Firstly, it is crucial for businesses to have a strong ethical culture and integrity standards in place. This includes promoting a zero-tolerance policy for bribery and corruption within the organization and ensuring that employees are aware of their responsibilities in adhering to anti-corruption l
aws.

Secondly, conducting thorough due diligence on potential international partners is essential. This involves assessing their reputation, business practices, and compliance with anti-corruption laws. It is important to verify that the partner has adequate controls and policies in place to prevent and
detect violations.

Additionally, businesses should establish clear and comprehensive anti-corruption policies and procedures that outline the expected behavior and compliance requirements for both employees and partners. These policies should be communicated effectively and regularly to all relevant stakeholders.

Furthermore, implementing robust internal controls and financial reporting systems is crucial. This includes maintaining accurate books and records with reasonable detail and ensuring that adequate controls are in place to prevent and detect any potential violations of anti-corruption laws.

Regular training and education programs should be provided to employees and partners to enhance their understanding of anti-corruption laws and the potential risks associated with non-compliance. This can help raise awareness and promote a culture of compliance within the organization.
Lastly, businesses should establish a mechanism for reporting and investigating any suspected violations of anti-corruption laws.

The legal risks associated with offering or accepting bribes in business partnerships can have serious consequences. These risks primarily fall into two significant categories: antitrust and competition laws, and anti-corruption laws.

Under antitrust and competition laws, it is important to treat business partners fairly and equitably. Engaging in activities such as price fixing or attempting to divide the market is illegal and can lead to legal repercussions. It is crucial to avoid participating in discussions with customers abo
ut business partner prices and terms to prevent potential legal consequences for IBM.

Anti-corruption laws also play a crucial role in mitigating legal risks. IBM can be held liable for corrupt activities conducted by business partners, such as bribing government officials or employees of government-owned entities, if IBM benefited from or was connected to the illegal activity. It is
essential to adhere to these laws and avoid any involvement in bribery or corruption.

To avoid these legal risks, it is important to act with integrity and follow legal obligations. IBM has a strong commitment to integrity and compliance, and as a publicly traded company, it is subject to the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), one of the world's most significant anti-corruption la

ws. The FCPA prohibits providing or even offering anything of value to a government official to improperly influence or gain a competitive advantage. This includes not only cash or gifts but also travel, meals, entertainment, employment, internships, and charitable contributions.

IBM can take several steps to mitigate the risk of FCPA violations by its business partners. Firstly, IBM can avoid entering into agreements that assign territory or customers, or coordinate strategies for different customers between either IBM and a BP or between other business partners. This will
help to prevent any tacit agreements that could potentially violate applicable law.

Secondly, IBM can ensure that its employees and business partners complete regular training on integrity and compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery statutes, such as the U.S Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. IBM employees complete an annual Business Conduct Guidelines training, while IBM Busi
ness Partners are required to complete a 30-minute online Integrity Training Course every 2 years.

Thirdly, IBM can maintain accurate books and records with reasonable detail and have adequate controls in place to prevent and detect violations. This is a requirement under the FCPA, and IBM can be held liable for the actions of its business partners if it knew or should have known of their illegal
activity benefiting IBM.

Finally, IBM can work closely with its legal team to ensure compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery statutes, especially with business partners. This is an area of significant focus for IBM Legal, and most enforcement actions have involved third parties, such as business partners. By taking
these steps, IBM can mitigate the risk of FCPA violations by its business partners and maintain its commitment to integrity and social responsibility.

IBM can ensure that it does not have actual knowledge or awareness of high probability of unlawful conduct by its business partners by implementing an effective compliance program. This program should include measures such as due diligence, training, and monitoring of business partners.

Firstly, IBM can conduct thorough due diligence on potential business partners before entering into any agreements or partnerships. This includes conducting background checks, reviewing their reputation, and assessing their compliance with applicable laws and regulations. By carefully selecting busi
ness partners with a strong track record of ethical conduct, IBM can minimize the risk of being associated with unlawful activities.

Secondly, IBM should provide comprehensive training to its employees and business partners on the company's code of conduct, policies, and relevant laws and regulations. This training should emphasize the importance of ethical behavior and compliance with anti-corruption laws, such as the Foreign Co

rrupt Practices Act (FCPA). By ensuring that employees and business partners are well-informed about their obligations and the potential risks associated with unlawful conduct, IBM can promote a culture of integrity and reduce the likelihood of non-compliance.

Furthermore, IBM should establish a system for monitoring and auditing its business partners' activities to detect any signs of potential misconduct. This can involve regular reviews of financial transactions, internal controls, and compliance procedures. By actively monitoring the activities of its

business partners, IBM can identify any red flags or suspicious behavior that may indicate a high probability of unlawful conduct. Prompt action can then be taken to address these issues and mitigate the risk of liability.

Violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) can have significant consequences for IBM and its business partners. Under the FCPA, IBM can be held liable for the actions of its business partners, especially if IBM knew or should have known about any illegal activities benefiting IBM. The FCPA r
equires IBM to have accurate books and records with reasonable detail and to have adequate controls in place to prevent and detect violations.

Failure to comply with the FCPA can result in fines for IBM, even if no actual bribery took place. Most enforcement actions related to the FCPA have involved third parties, such as business partners, and this remains a focus of U.S regulators. Therefore, it is crucial for IBM and its business partne
rs to ensure compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery statutes, such as the FCPA.

To stay compliant, IBM business partners are required to complete a no-cost online Integrity training course every two years. This training helps ensure a full understanding of the FCPA and other relevant laws. IBM also recommends having a focal point in your organization responsible for compliance
and business controls. Regularly checking Partnerworld for updates and requesting support from IBM can also help in staying compliant.

Non-compliance with the FCPA can result in termination of business partnerships and damage to IBM's reputation. Therefore, it is essential for IBM and its business partners to act with integrity, follow the IBM Code of Conduct, and maintain accurate records demonstrating compliance with the FCPA and
other applicable laws.
To understand the guidelines and best practices for working with IBM business partners, including resellers and distributors, there are several resources available:

1. IBM Business Partner Code of Conduct: This document defines the minimum business conduct and practice standards that IBM business partners are expected to comply with in their relationship with IBM. It provides guidance on ethical behavior, compliance with laws and regulations, and maintaining th
e highest level of integrity.

2. Guidelines for Working With IBM Business Partners: This internal document outlines IBM's policies and practices on various topics when supporting business partners. It covers areas such as partner selection, engagement models, joint marketing, and sales strategies. It provides insights into how I
BM collaborates with its partners and sets expectations for a successful partnership.

3. IBM Partner Ecosystem Contract Documents: This resource provides contract templates for different types of business partner agreements, including Business Partner Agreement (BPA), Embed Solution Agreement (ESA), Cloud Marketplace, and more. These documents outline the legal terms and conditions f
or partnering with IBM and help ensure compliance with contractual obligations.

Working with business partners, such as resellers and distributors, differs from direct sales in several ways. Firstly, business partners are independent entities from IBM, which means they determine their own marketing strategy, set their own pricing and terms, and may even compete with each other.
This independence can result in additional legal risks for IBM when working with business partners.

One of the key differences between working with business partners and direct sales is that business partners may resell IBM products to end-users under their own terms and conditions. This means that IBM must ensure that its terms and conditions are flowed down to the end-users through the business

partners. Additionally, IBM pays special attention to the discounts it provides to distributors, resellers, and business partners through special bids. Excessive discounts run the risk of being passed on to government officials, or used to create slush funds, so IBM closely scrutinizes the justifica
tions for providing discounts, as well as their amounts.

Another area of legal risk when working with business partners is compliance with foreign transaction management policies. IBM requires that business partners comply with these policies and cooperate in business compliance audits. Additionally, confidentiality agreements must be in place to protect
IBM's intellectual property and other sensitive information.

In summary, working with business partners such as resellers and distributors differs from direct sales in that business partners are independent entities from IBM and may resell IBM products under their own terms and conditions.

In the context of IBM business partners, resellers and distributors are both types of partners who play important roles in the distribution of IBM products and services. However, there are some key differences between the two.

Resellers are independent entities who own the relationship with their end user customer. They are responsible for setting their own pricing and terms with their customer, and may also compete with IBM directly for business. Resellers include Business Partners who resell under the BPA to End Users,
as well as Cloud Marketplace Resellers who resell certain IBM offerings digitally. It is important to note that resellers must flow down IBM terms for acceptance to the End Users.

On the other hand, distributors are a type of reseller that resells only to other IBM resellers. They provide support and other benefits to resellers that IBM otherwise would have to provide. Distributors are required to ensure their associated IBM resellers and systems integrators have an End User

order in place before an order is submitted to IBM. IBM will validate Firm Order Policy (FOP) for the following transactions prior to fulfillment: All special bid hardware orders above predefined clip level and all software orders where the combined daily order(s) for the same BP and the same end us
er is above the predefined clip level.

Resellers, including distributors, have the responsibility of flowing down IBM terms to their end users. This means that they must ensure that the required IBM terms for software, hardware products, cloud services, and professional services are passed down to their customers and that these terms are
accepted by the end users. This is important for several reasons.

Firstly, flowing down IBM terms ensures that the end users are aware of and agree to the terms and conditions set by IBM. This helps to establish a clear understanding of the rights and obligations of both parties involved in the transaction.

Secondly, by flowing down IBM terms, resellers and distributors ensure compliance with IBM's policies and guidelines. This helps to maintain consistency and standardization in the use and distribution of IBM products and services.

Additionally, flowing down IBM terms helps to protect the interests of both IBM and the end users. It ensures that the end users receive the necessary support, warranties, and maintenance services from IBM or its authorized partners. It also helps to prevent unauthorized use or misuse of IBM product
s and services.

Furthermore, flowing down IBM terms helps to mitigate legal risks and potential conflicts. It establishes a contractual framework that governs the relationship between the reseller, distributor, and end user, reducing the likelihood of misunderstandings or disputes.

Overall, the responsibility of flowing down IBM terms to end users is crucial for maintaining transparency, compliance, and a mutually beneficial relationship between all parties involved in the distribution and use of IBM products and services.

Resellers, including distributors, are independent entities from IBM and thus determine their own marketing strategies, pricing, and terms when working with IBM. They may compete with each other and must flow down IBM terms for acceptance to the end users. It is important to note that working with r
esellers is different from direct sales, and there are key differences and increased areas of legal risk when working with them.

Resellers may engage in bid rigging or collusion, which are illegal practices that involve coordinating pricing in favor of a pre-agreed winner or agreeing to offer only certain pricing or maintain certain pricing levels. To prevent these practices, IBM allows resellers to independently set their ow
n pricing and terms, as well as the solution configuration that they are offering to their clients.

IBM pays special attention to the discounts it provides to distributors, resellers, and business partners through special bids. Excessive discounts run the risk of being passed on to government officials or used to create slush funds, so IBM closely scrutinizes the justifications for providing disco
unts, as well as their amounts. IBM also strives to ensure that the end user prices that third parties quote to IBM are the actual prices their end users ultimately pay.

To accomplish this, IBM puts limits around the Maximum End User Price, conducts post-ship verification, and issues transparency letters. IBM also assesses margins, discounts, and the proposed route to market.

When working with IBM, there are two types of partners that play a role in the distribution process: resellers and distributors. Resellers are independent entities from IBM that resell IBM products and services to end-users. They determine their own marketing strategy, set their own pricing and term

s, and may compete with each other. Resellers must flow down IBM terms for acceptance to the end-users. Distributors, on the other hand, are a type of reseller that resells only to other IBM resellers. They provide support and other benefits to resellers that IBM otherwise would have to provide.

The key difference between resellers and distributors is that distributors serve as intermediaries between IBM and resellers, while resellers sell directly to end-users. Distributors are responsible for managing the relationships with resellers, providing them with support, and ensuring that they ha

ve the resources they need to sell IBM products and services effectively. Distributors also help to streamline the distribution process by consolidating orders from multiple resellers and providing a single point of contact for IBM.

It's important to note that working with business partners is different from direct sales. Business partners, including resellers and distributors, are independent entities from IBM and can sell for IBM competitors. This creates increased areas of legal risk when working with resellers compared to d
irect sales. Additionally, it's important to understand that the Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA) program is not an alternative to resell.

ESA business partners provide L1 and L2 support for the solutions they offer, which means they are responsible for providing technical assistance and resolving issues related to the embedded IBM technology in their solutions. They also retain IBM software and/or hardware entitlement and title, and o

ffer a single price for their solution that includes IBM technology. The solution is offered under the business partner's end user agreement, and the partner is contracted under the Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA).

On the other hand, resellers pass on IBM software and/or hardware entitlement and title to the end user, and set their own pricing for IBM offerings. They are responsible for obtaining acceptance of IBM end user terms, and IBM provides L1 and L2 support. Resellers are contracted under the Business P
artner Agreement.

The ESA contract offers flexible terms and pricing for the IBM technology that is embedded in the partner solution, allowing them to control and predict their costs. IBM works with the partner to create the right commercial model construct in the ESA that supports how they position and sell their so
lution into the market. Signing an ESA unlocks benefits such as technical expertise to support them through the integration phase of embedding the IBM technology.

In summary, ESA business partners provide more comprehensive support for their solutions, including technical assistance and issue resolution, while also retaining entitlement and title for IBM technology. Resellers, on the other hand, pass on entitlement and title to the end user and provide less c
omprehensive support, with IBM providing L1 and L2 support.

In an Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA), the ownership and entitlement of IBM technology remain with the ESA business partner (BP). The ESA BP retains the software (SW)/Software as a Service (SaaS) entitlement and hardware (HW) title for the IBM technology included in their solution. They also provi
de Level 1 (L1) and Level 2 (L2) support for the solution.

On the other hand, in a reseller agreement, the reseller passes on the SW/SaaS entitlement and HW title to the end user. The reseller sets their own pricing for the IBM offerings and obtains acceptance of IBM's end user terms. IBM provides L1 and L2 support in this case.

In terms of pricing, an ESA BP offers a single price for their solution, which includes the IBM technology. The pricing is determined by the ESA BP and is part of their end user agreement. In contrast, a reseller separately prices the IBM components as they are being sold "as is" and not as part of
a solution.

It's important to note that the ESA business partner's solution must be distinct from the IBM offerings included in the solution. The ESA model allows the partner to leverage IBM technology to enhance their solution, while the reseller model involves marketing IBM technology as is under IBM branding
and terms to end users.

These differences in ownership, entitlement, and pricing between ESA and reseller agreements provide flexibility for partners to choose the most suitable model for their business and go-to-market strategy.

The key differences between an Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA) and regular business partners such as resellers and distributors lie in the nature of their relationship with IBM and the way they operate. Under an ESA, a business partner is not simply reselling IBM technology as is, under IBM's bran
ding and terms. Instead, an ESA involves a deeper level of collaboration and customization.

Unlike resellers and distributors, who are independent entities from IBM, business partners under an ESA work closely with IBM to develop and embed IBM technology into their own solutions. This means that they have the ability to customize and integrate IBM technology into their own products or serv
ices, creating a unique offering for their customers.

Resellers, on the other hand, primarily focus on reselling IBM technology to end users. They operate independently from IBM and have the freedom to determine their own marketing strategies, pricing, and terms. Resellers may also compete with each other in the market.

Distributors, which are a type of reseller, have a slightly different role. They resell IBM technology exclusively to other IBM resellers, providing support and additional benefits to these resellers that IBM would otherwise have to provide. Distributors act as intermediaries between IBM and the res
eller channel.

It is important to note that working with business partners under an ESA involves a different set of requirements and use cases compared to resellers and distributors. ESA partners collaborate with IBM to create customized solutions, while resellers primarily focus on selling IBM technology as is.
Partnering with IBM under an Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA) offers several benefits compared to a traditional reseller arrangement.

Firstly, under an ESA, a business partner has the opportunity to combine IBM technology with their own value-add to create a BP-branded repeatable solution. This means that the partner can customize and enhance the IBM technology to meet the specific needs of their customers, providing a unique and
differentiated offering in the market.

Secondly, with an ESA, the business partner retains the software, software-as-a-service (SaaS) entitlement, and hardware title, giving them more control over the solution they are offering. This allows the partner to have greater flexibility in pricing and packaging their solution, tailoring it to t
he specific requirements of their target market.

Additionally, under an ESA, the business partner provides Level 1 and Level 2 support for the solution. This means that they are responsible for assisting their customers with any technical issues or inquiries related to the solution. This level of support ensures that the partner can deliver a seam
less and high-quality customer experience, building trust and loyalty with their clients.

Furthermore, the solution offered under an ESA is governed by the business partner's own End User Agreement, rather than IBM's terms. This gives the partner more control over the contractual terms and conditions, allowing them to align the agreement with their business strategy and objectives.
It is important to note that an ESA is not an alternative to reselling IBM technology under IBM branding and terms.

An ESA business partner creates a BP-branded repeatable solution by combining IBM technology with their own value-add. This means that the business partner takes the IBM technology and enhances it with their own intellectual property or services to create a unique solution. The value-add provided by
the business partner must be significant and material, and it should differentiate their solution from simply reselling IBM technology under IBM's branding and terms.

When selling the solution, the ESA business partner offers it under their own contract terms, known as the End User Agreement. This is in contrast to a regular reseller who must pass on IBM's standard terms to their end users. The ESA business partner retains the IBM software or software-as-a-servic
e entitlement and hardware title, and they provide a single price for their solution, which includes the IBM technology.

In terms of support, the ESA business partner is responsible for providing Level 1 and Level 2 support for their solution. This means that they handle the initial support inquiries and troubleshooting, as well as more advanced technical support. They are also obligated to provide support for the IBM
content within their solution, ensuring that it functions properly and meets the end user's needs.

It's important to note that the support obligations for an ESA business partner are greater compared to a reseller. The ESA business partner has a higher level of responsibility for the solution, especially the IBM content within it. On the other hand, a reseller does not have the same support oblig
ations for the IBM technology they are reselling.

The key difference between an Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA) and a Business Partner Agreement (BPA) lies in the nature of the partnership and the offerings provided. Under an ESA, a business partner combines IBM technology with their own value-add to create a BP-branded repeatable solution, which

is distinct from the IBM offerings included in the solution. The business partner retains IBM software or hardware entitlement and provides L1 and L2 support for the solution. The solution is sold to the end user client under the business partner's own contract terms.

On the other hand, under a BPA, the business partner markets IBM technology as is, under IBM branding and terms, to end users. The business partner passes on IBM software or hardware entitlement to the end user and sets their own pricing for IBM offerings. IBM provides L1 and L2 support for the solu
tion, and the business partner is contracted under the Business Partner Agreement.

It is important to distinguish between an ESA and a BPA because the terms and obligations differ for each type of agreement. With an ESA, the business partner has the flexibility to create and offer solutions that meet the specific requirements of industries, incorporating their own value-add. The b
usiness partner retains control over the solution and can sell it under their own contract terms. They also have the responsibility of providing support for the solution.
On the other hand, with a BPA, the business partner acts as a reseller of IBM technology, marketing it under IBM branding and terms.

IBM conducts business compliance audits periodically, which are conducted by their own IBM Corporate Assurance and Advisory Services team, as well as other teams that may request information for compliance audits. The frequency of these audits is not specified in the provided documentation.

If non-compliance is detected during one of these audits, IBM expects their business partners to cooperate with them. Business partners are required to provide requested information to IBM during a compliance audit or other review as needed to support IBM business transactions.

If non-compliance is found, IBM may take action to address the issue, which could include terminating the business relationship with the non-compliant partner. It is important for business partners to follow IBM's policies and guidelines to ensure compliance and maintain a positive relationship with
IBM.

Compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery statutes, such as the U.S Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, is an area of significant focus for IBM Legal, especially with business partners. Most enforcement actions have involved third parties, such as business partners, and remain a focus of U.S regul
ators. Under the FCPA, IBM can be liable for the actions of its business partners, especially if IBM knew or should have known of the illegal activity benefiting IBM.
Therefore, it is crucial for business partners to be transparent and follow IBM's policies and guidelines to avoid any non-compliance issues during a compliance audit.

Good record-keeping is important for business partners because it allows them to quickly provide the level of detail that would be required at a compliance review in a timely manner. As mentioned in the documentation, IBM requires business partners to keep and maintain all IBM transaction records fo

r a minimum of 3 years from the date of the transaction. IBM or its auditor may periodically review business partner transactions, including special bid transactions, and business partners are expected to provide requested information to IBM during a compliance audit or other review as needed to sup
port IBM business transactions.

In addition, IBM distributors also have responsibility in this area to ensure their business partners are compliant. This means that business partners must maintain accurate records not only for their own benefit but also to ensure that they are meeting IBM's compliance requirements. Failure to main
tain accurate records could result in penalties or other consequences, which could negatively impact the business partner's relationship with IBM.

Overall, good record-keeping is an essential part of compliance for business partners working with IBM. Building a successful partnership with IBM involves following some best practices and taking advantage of the available resources and support. Here are some key points to consider:

1. Know your partner: Take the time to understand your partner's strengths and capabilities. This knowledge will help you identify areas where you can collaborate effectively and leverage each other's expertise.
2. Set joint expectations: Clearly define the roles and responsibilities of both parties in the partnership. This will ensure that everyone is on the same page and working towards common goals.
3. Communicate openly: Be transparent and clear in front of clients about how you and IBM work together. This will build trust and confidence in the partnership.
4. Share opportunities: Collaborate with your partner and IBM to identify and share business opportunities. This mutual sharing of opportunities will help strengthen the partnership and extend trust.

5. Take advantage of resources: IBM offers a range of resources and support for partners. These include partner-facing sales and technical resources, dedicated territories, and compensation for co-selling. Make sure to utilize these resources to enhance your partnership and drive success.

6. Practice integrity: Both IBM and its partners should maintain a high standard of integrity in all interactions with clients. Trustworthy actions and ethical business practices are essential for building successful business relationships.

7. Stay updated: Participate in the IBM Relationship Revalidation Program, which requires partners to provide updated information about their ownership and key contacts. This program ensures that the partnership remains current and aligned with IBM's standards.

d in the ESA allow partners to obtain rights to embed IBM's software or hardware technology into their products, solutions, or services, which they can then sell to their clients.

This flexibility allows partners to control and predict their costs, as they can choose the pricing structure that aligns with their business model and m

arket strategy. By having the ability to set a single price for their solution, which includes the IBM technology, partners can simplify their pricing and make it more attractive to their end-user clients.

Furthermore, the ESA enables partners to retain the IBM software or SaaS entitlement and hardware title, giving them ownership and control over the embedded IBM technology. This allows partners to market and sell the solution under their own brand, strengthening their relationship with their end cus
tomers. Additionally, partners are responsible for providing Level 1 and Level 2 support for the solution, ensuring that they have direct control over the customer experience.
Overall, the ESA contract offers partners the flexibility to leverage IBM's innovative and market-tested technologies while tailoring their solution to meet the specific needs of their customers.

The key requirements for a partner to obtain an Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA) with IBM are centered around the partner's solution use case and the value it delivers in relation to the IBM technology being embedded. The partner must have a clear understanding of how their solution incorporates an
d enhances IBM's software or hardware technology.

Under an ESA, the partner is responsible for marketing and selling the solution under their own brand, and they maintain the direct relationship with the end customer. This means that the partner has the freedom to position and sell their solution in the market according to their own strategy.

The ESA contract offers flexible terms and pricing for the IBM technology that is embedded in the partner's solution. This allows the partner to have control over and predict their costs associated with the IBM technology. The commercial model construct in the ESA is tailored to support how the part
ner wants to position and sell their solution.

It is important to note that an ESA is not an alternative to reselling IBM technology. The characteristics of an ESA differ significantly from those of regular business partners, such as resellers and distributors. In an ESA, the partner is not simply reselling IBM technology under IBM's branding an
d terms. Instead, the partner combines the IBM technology with their own value-add to create a BP-branded repeatable solution.

If IBM fails to comply with the requirements of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), it could face significant fines and penalties. These penalties could include civil and criminal liability, fines, imprisonment, suspension or debarment, bid protests, contract termination, liability under overl

apping rules, employee disciplinary action, and damage to IBM's brand or reputation. Additionally, corruption activities by business partners that benefit IBM or are connected to the sale of IBM offerings could bring direct government action against IBM.

To mitigate these risks, it is important for IBM to adhere to the applicable rules and regulations, including the FCPA. IBM should ensure that all employees and business partners are aware of and trained on these requirements. IBM should also conduct due diligence on its business partners to ensure

that they are reputable and comply with applicable laws and regulations. Additionally, IBM should have strong internal controls and compliance programs in place to detect and prevent any potential violations of the FCPA. By taking these steps, IBM can avoid significant repercussions that could impac
t its ability to do work with the government and its bottom line.

IBM ensures adequate internal controls and accurate record-keeping to prevent violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) through a comprehensive approach. Firstly, IBM's Legal department places significant focus on compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery statutes, such as the FC
PA. This includes ensuring compliance with the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which applies to IBM and its Business Partners (BPs).

To prevent violations, IBM maintains a proper system of internal controls. These internal controls are designed to prevent and detect any potential violations of the FCPA. IBM's internal controls encompass various aspects of the business, including financial transactions, expense reports, and suppor

ting receipts. The company's books and records must accurately reflect all transactions in reasonable detail, including reported financial statements and records kept in the ordinary course of business.

IBM's internal controls provisions do not have materiality requirements, meaning that even minor violations can be considered significant. This makes it easier for regulators to demonstrate that a company has violated the FCPA's books and records and internal controls provisions.

Furthermore, IBM recognizes the importance of its Business Partners in compliance efforts. Most enforcement actions related to the FCPA involve third parties, such as BPs. IBM can be held liable for the actions of its BPs if it knew or should have known about their illegal activities benefiting IBM.
Therefore, IBM works closely with its BPs to ensure their compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws.

The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) is a significant anti-corruption law that applies to IBM as a US publicly traded company. The FCPA has several requirements that IBM must comply with to avoid fines and legal repercussions.

One of the main requirements of the FCPA is that IBM must have accurate books and records with reasonable detail and adequate controls in place to prevent and detect violations. This means that IBM must keep detailed records of all financial transactions and ensure that there are proper controls in
place to prevent bribery and corruption. Failure to comply with this requirement can result in fines for IBM, even if no actual bribery took place.

Another important requirement of the FCPA is that IBM must prohibit individuals and businesses from offering anything of value to foreign government officials in order to improperly obtain or retain business. This means that IBM cannot offer bribes or other incentives to foreign government officials
to gain a competitive advantage. IBM must also ensure that its business partners comply with this requirement, as IBM can be held liable for the actions of its partners.

Compliance with the FCPA is important for IBM because it helps to ensure that the company operates with integrity and avoids legal and financial risks. Acting with integrity is not only good for business, but it is also critical for meeting legal obligations. The FCPA is a significant anti-corruptio
n law that is enforced by US regulators, and failure to comply with its requirements can result in fines and legal action.

When creating partnering strategies and engaging with partners, there are several best practices that can be followed:

1. Start with the client and the territory: Understand the client's requirements and the specific territory you are targeting. This will help you tailor your approach and align your strategies with the client's needs.

2. Know client requirements: Gain a deep understanding of the client's business objectives, challenges, and priorities. This will enable you to offer relevant solutions and position yourself as a valuable partner.

3. Understand Business Partner relationships with clients: Familiarize yourself with the existing relationships your partners have with clients. This will help you identify potential synergies and areas for collaboration.

4. Engage with your Business Partner: Establish open lines of communication and build a strong relationship with your partners. Regular discussions and collaboration will foster trust and enhance the partnership.

5. Engage early in the client buy cycle: Get involved in the client's decision-making process as early as possible. By doing so, you can influence their requirements and position your partnership as a preferred choice.

6. Develop a joint IBM-Business Partner account win plan: Create a comprehensive plan that outlines the strategies, goals, and actions required to win new accounts. Collaborate with your partners to ensure alignment and maximize success.
7. Collaborate as a team in front of the client: Present a united front when engaging with clients. Work together with your partners to showcase your combined expertise and capabilities.
8. Hold joint sales calls: Involve your partners in sales calls to leverage their knowledge and expertise. This will demonstrate a unified approach and provide a holistic solution to the client.
From an IBM point of view, there are five key expectations from business partners:
1. Integrity: IBM expects business partners to uphold high ethical standards and act with integrity in all business dealings.
2. Courtesy: IBM values respectful and professional behavior from its business partners, including effective communication and collaboration.

3. Investment in skills, services, solutions, and client relationships: IBM expects business partners to continuously invest in their skills and capabilities, as well as in developing innovative solutions and maintaining strong client relationships.

4. Active contribution to progress and close deals: IBM encourages business partners to actively contribute to the progress of joint projects and initiatives, as well as to actively participate in closing deals and acquiring new clients.

5. Joint success and client satisfaction: IBM seeks business partners who are committed to achieving joint success and ensuring client satisfaction. This includes delivering high-quality solutions and services that meet client needs.
For more information on IBM's expectations from business partners, you can refer to the provided documentation.

Under the Embedded Solution Agreement (ESA), a business partner is not simply reselling IBM technology as is under IBM's branding and terms. The key difference between ESA and regular business partners such as resellers and distributors lies in the requirements and use cases.

In the case of ESA, the business partner combines IBM technology with their own value-add to create a BP-branded repeatable solution, known as an "Embedded Solution." The ESA business partner retains IBM software/SaaS entitlement and hardware title. They offer the solution to the end user client und
er their own end user agreement, with a single price that includes IBM technology.
Additionally, the ESA business partner provides Level 1 and Level 2 support for the solution. The agreement is contracted under the Embedded Solution Agreement.

On the other hand, regular resellers market IBM technology as is, under IBM branding and terms, to end users. They pass software/SaaS entitlement and hardware title to the end user and set their own pricing for IBM offerings. IBM provides Level 1 and Level 2 support in this case. The agreement is co
ntracted under the Business Partner Agreement.
It is important to note that the Embedded Solution offered under ESA must be distinct from the IBM offerings included in the solution.
For more information and details about the characteristics of ESA partners compared to resellers and distributors, you can refer to the provided documentation.

Some common examples of FCPA (Foreign Corrupt Practices Act) violations include making improper payments or bribes to government officials or employees of government-owned entities (GOEs), providing gifts or lavish entertainment to influence business decisions, and engaging in fraudulent accounting
practices to conceal improper payments. These violations can occur both within the United States and internationally.

The consequences for companies found guilty of noncompliance with the FCPA can be severe. They may face civil liability, criminal liability (including fines and imprisonment), suspension or debarment from government contracts, bid protests, contract termination, liability under overlapping rules, em

ployee disciplinary action, and damage to their brand or reputation. Companies can be held directly liable for their own conduct or indirectly liable for the actions of third parties, such as business partners, if they knew or should have known about the illegal activities benefiting the company.

It is important for companies to maintain proper systems of internal controls to prevent and detect FCPA violations. The FCPA requires companies to have accurate books and records with reasonable detail and adequate controls in place to prevent and detect violations. It is worth noting that 90% of F
CPA cases involve third parties, highlighting the importance of due diligence and monitoring of business partners to ensure compliance with anti-corruption and anti-bribery statutes.

Overall, companies should be aware of the FCPA's provisions, implement robust compliance programs, conduct thorough due diligence on business partners, and maintain accurate records to avoid FCPA violations and the associated consequences.

Companies can avoid legal consequences and maintain ethical business practices when working with foreign governments and officials by adhering to anti-bribery and anti-corruption laws, such as the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) in the US. It is crucial for companies to understand and comply wi
th these laws to mitigate the risk of bribery and corruption.
To ensure ethical business practices, companies should:

1. Implement robust compliance programs: Companies should establish comprehensive compliance programs that include policies, procedures, and training to educate employees and business partners about anti-bribery laws and ethical standards. IBM, for example, requires its employees and business partne
rs to complete annual integrity training courses.

2. Conduct due diligence: Before engaging with foreign governments or officials, companies should conduct thorough due diligence to assess the reputation and integrity of potential partners. This includes evaluating their track record, conducting background checks, and assessing their compliance wit
h anti-bribery laws.

3. Maintain transparency and accurate records: It is essential for companies to maintain accurate and transparent records of all transactions and interactions with foreign governments and officials. This includes documenting the purpose, nature, and value of any payments or benefits provided.

4. Prohibit facilitation payments: Facilitation payments, also known as "grease payments," are small payments made to expedite routine government actions. Companies should have clear policies that prohibit facilitation payments, as they can still be considered bribes under anti-corruption laws.

The U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) has three main elements. Firstly, the anti-bribery provisions prohibit companies from providing or even offering anything of value to a government official in order to improperly influence or gain a competitive advantage. This means that companies cannot
engage in bribery or corruption practices when dealing with government officials.

Secondly, the FCPA requires companies to have accurate books and records with reasonable detail. This means that companies must maintain transparent and accurate financial records that reflect their business transactions. It is important for companies to have proper accounting practices in place to
ensure compliance with this requirement.

Lastly, the FCPA mandates that companies have adequate controls in place to prevent and detect violations of the anti-bribery provisions. This means that companies must establish internal controls and procedures to identify and prevent any potential bribery or corruption activities. These controls a
re crucial in mitigating the risk of illegal activities and ensuring compliance with the law.

It is important for companies to comply with the FCPA for several reasons. Firstly, non-compliance can result in significant legal and financial consequences. The U.S. government has collected billions of dollars in fines from FCPA violations, and companies found guilty of non-compliance can face he
fty penalties. Compliance with the FCPA helps companies avoid these financial risks.

Secondly, compliance with the FCPA is essential for maintaining a company's reputation and credibility. Engaging in bribery or corruption practices can severely damage a company's image and trustworthiness.
